Ever just want to rip a pipe out of a wall and crack someone over the head?   Don't try this at home or at your place of business :)

While my play time on Steam will appear non existent, I have played Condemned every year since it's 2005 introduction. Containing multiple endings, Condemned, a first person psychological horror, offers the player a chance to experience some of the most well implemented melee combat that has ever been produced.  A great variety of melee weapons are available and weapons such as rebar, pipes and locker doors can be pulled literally right out of the environment.

Weapons are not limited to Melee.  Ranged weapons are limited in availability and include but are not limited to rifles, pistols and shotguns.  Ammo is limited to what is loaded in the weapon so shots count.  Run out of ammo?  Ranged weapons also double as melee weapons.  Melee weapons are rated by damage, swing speed, block time and reach.

Condemned builds great atmosphere. Its story is told through the brilliance of forensic investigation using forensic tools and activley involves you in crime scene investigations. Condemned was released in 2005 and you can tell by the games character modelling however the environment that the game presents remains outstanding. The game's engine loads as fast as any engine I've seen and keeps load times to a bare minimum.  Great use of sound and nice visuals complement the immersive story.

reviewText:
This was a game I picked up based on a bunch of recommendations from various imageboards and a few friends. For what it’s worth, Condemned: Criminal Origins lives up to the hype and immerses you in a world of filth, horror, and redemption. You play the role of Ethan Thomas, a FBI agent tasked with tracking down serial killers, who ends up wrongfully accused of a crime he didn’t commit. Your desire for exoneration drives you to follow a trail of madness with only your FBI lab tools and intuition to guide you.

During the game, you will be spending your time doing one of the following: combat or forensics. In the combat phase, gameplay resembles that of a first-person shooter or beat-em-up requiring you to either aim carefully or time your blocking and movement so as to avoid taking damage. You also get a taser which is extremely useful in situations where you are facing groups or enemies with firearms.

For the forensic phase, you will draw upon an array of tools to scan the surrounding area and collect the necessary information to continue the storyline. The implement used is automatically decided on depending on the circumstance and you are only required to point it at the very obvious area of interest in just about every instance, so there really isn’t much of a challenge. It’s basically just a vehicle used to drive the story forward. Regarding the story, everything is “good enough” and just about all the loose ends get tied up by the end so you won’t need to draw your own conclusions for the most part.

Earlier in my backlog, I came across another murder mystery with a few similar themes (Deadly Premonition) and I’d have to say this is definitely the better of the two, at least story-wise. Be sure to pick it up if you want a little horror-mystery hybrid in your life.

reviewText:
Condemned is a deeply atmospheric and violent horror game.

You're a crime scene investigator: you start off by visiting a crime scene and use forensic tools to determine what happened there. After the initial investigation you find out the suspect is still in the building and go to corner him, but in a turn of events he manages to grab your pistol and you get conked out. You wake up to find you're wanted for two murders you didn't commit and must now clear your name by tracking down this maniac killer through some of the eeriest parts of the city.

Condemned is a standout game when it comes to horror because of its immersive level design. Environments are extremely well fleshed out and thick with atmosphere. The gritty realistic detail in textures is particularly impressive, especially for a 2005 game, and because the horror and scares are subtle and more psychological in nature there is a genuine tenseness when exploring a new area. Not to mention that most of the derelict places you wander through are so dark you're forced to go in with just a flashlight to light your way... it definitely recalls some of my creepier urban exploration adventures!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=271182752
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=271142655
Besides having an immersive horror atmosphere, Condemned shines in its brutal melee combat. It's especially impressive how realistic the enemies movements to your blows are. The most unique part of the combat is you can pull your weapon arsenal right from the environment: pry out a rebar pipe, rip the door from a locker, snatch a metal sign to get bloodied up - every location has its own host of makeshift weapons to put to good use. Oh, and I like that the enemy AI will fight each other if one of them accidentally hits the other - nice touch.

Admittedly the gameplay when it comes to the forensic stuff is forcibly linear. They shoehorn you into only being able to use one type of scanner or tool when you have an array at your disposal and you are basically only doing it to move the story along. It's still fairly interesting and interactive though, and the findings you report will give you clues into what's really going on and what to do next.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=250811336
All in all, I recommend checking this out if you're looking to explore a genuinely tense game spiced up with savage melee encounters and an engaging story. If you've played FEAR you know these guys will deliver on a solid horror game.

reviewText:
Condemned: Criminal Origins features a story of a detective who ends up on the run due to strange circumstances. He's after a demented serial killer, and to catch him and clear his name, he must take to the underbelly of the city. However, something strange is going on. Homeless people that have taken to living in abandoned buildings and tunnels are acting needlessly aggressive and violent. But it's more than just that, something darker, more sinister is thriving in the unseen places of this city...

Featuring a rather well-done and satisfying melee-focused combat system (seriously, not exaggerating, it has one of the best melee combat systems in a first-person type of game in my opinion), you'll find yourself exploring 10 different locations through the game, and periodically using some gadgets and gizmos for forensic sciences to try and track your killer. But of course, the best parts of the game aren't the combat or the detective work (though neither are bad!).

The horror element in this game doesn't really fully reveal itself until the later half of the game, which I think is an interesting choice. The atmosphere in this game is fantastic for certain, but things start to get seriously creepy and a bit unpredictable about half-way in. It's interesting as most horror games like to sort of blow their load at the start and then fuel the survival element in the second half of the game with more and more difficult enemies. This game does get harder per say, but its horror element really starts to shine in its second half, and I even think there may be less enemies in the second half of the game as well.

There are some very clever scares here, but honestly most of the horror comes from a really dreary atmosphere the game has, which is particularly strong in three specific locations/chapters in the later half. The story is interesting, though in this titles case I think you'll end off with more questions than answers (which might be for the best, as the sequel shows).

It's not perfect. Most notably, the final chapter and boss are a bit disappointing (a shame as they're promising in concept but just not executed all that well), but the game is definitely worth checking out for any horror enthusiasts out there. Most of the title has excellent execution and atmosphere, and it truly is one of the best horror games to have released in the last 10 years.

reviewText:
Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first-person psychological horror game by Monolith, renown for kickstarting the F.E.A.R. franchise, where the player takes the role of Ethan Thomas, an FBI agent who gets framed by a serial killer for killing his colleagues during a crime investigation. This sets motion for the events that are to follow in which Ethan, guided by his only trustworthy ally who believes he was not behind the killings, has to hunt down the real serial killer. In the meantime, Ethan also begins noticing the sudden increase in some very peculiar events that occur around him and to almost every person he meets.

As a survival horror, Condemned: Criminal Origins is a “beautiful” experience. What I mean by that is that the game focuses more on eerie atmosphere and enigmas reminiscent of games like Penumbra. No overuse of cheap jump scares and excessive gory imagery. For me, this is what I always wanted in a horror game which in recent years Frictional Games have always successfully provided for my fix. But even when the game ends up using these tropes for one or two occasions, they are well placed in the game and not overstay their welcome. Sure, the game also throws in a few supernatural elements, which I do not want spoil for obvious reasons, into the mix later on that make the experience even more petrifying. Frankly, there are quite a number of things which Condemned: Criminal Origins nails perfectly, and one of them is certainly the stellar audio design. The moment you hear all that tromping upstairs or around you, you truly start believing you could bend a steel pipe by how tense your butt cheeks are. I am not joking when I am saying that I occasionally pondered whether the real name of this game should have been Condemned: The Ferret Tromping. Likewise, the great soundtrack compliments the atmosphere and fits with the tone of the game. You can feel the cold shivers running down your spine. Bloody violins.

When not wetting your pants like a sissy, Condemned’s gameplay is mostly all about melee encounters. Even though you can use a few firearms, their ammunition limitation makes them only worthwhile and effective in the short term. I suppose the best firearm is the taser as it can momentarily stun your enemies, giving you a window of opportunity to either steal their weapons or take an effortless shot at them, but it is useless against boss fights. Instead, you will be spending the majority of the time with melee objects such as pipes, planks, sledgehammers, axes, crowbars and many more, smacking your opponents to death. Whilst the melee combat might not feel exactly like in Chivalry: Medieval Warfare in terms of variety of moves, every swing has a “weight” to it. Thereby every miss you make can decide whether you will stay alive any longer. Now each weapon in the game has its own benefits and downsides. Some can deal more damage but are slower to manoeuvre and others deal less damage but are swifter. Honestly, the melee combat is perhaps amongst the best aspects of this game as it makes you think and move tactically. It feels satisfying too.

For a horror game, I think the AI in here is exceptional. Most of the human enemies will try to play hide and seek rather than simply attacking the player the moment they are spotted. Moreover, they do not just hide in one spot; they constantly switch their positions. This makes encounters unpredictable and always different in each playthrough. Naturally, there are a couple of scripted moments designed specifically to scare the player in the game, but thankfully these are very few.

In terms of graphical fidelity, the game shows its age quite clearly. There is no denying in saying that it feels visually “consolised” as the textures do look all muddy and the excessive bloom (when turned on) reminds me of games on a Xbox 360 from 2006. But in terms of art direction, it does a good job on the various designs of the enemies you can come across and the environments that almost feel like you actually visited them in real life. Additionally, the second half of the game, from a level design stand point, is much better and scarier.

Of course, the game is not without its fair share of problems. First off, there are sections in the game which require you to take down some sort of a obstacle like a (wooden) door to advance to the next area. Being in the possession of an axe most of the time, at least in my case, one would think that would suffice. But you thought wrong as the game explicitly tells the player that it requires a specific weapon, like a sledgehammer, to take it down instead. This leads to going back and doing a couple of fetch-quests looking for the right item. Plus, you cannot guess what item  will require next time. Luckily, the aforementioned item generally tends to be nearby. Now, my main gripe with this is the simple fact that it is purely stupid. I have an axe, why cannot I take it down? Why do I need a different weapon which has pretty much an identical function as an axe in the game’s context?

Then there is Ethan’s walking pace and stamina. The game gives the player the ability to sprint, but only lasts as long as “running” from one end of the room to the next.  It is not even running; it is a very slow jog. You see, it totally makes sense walking slowly in the more atmospheric segments of the game where you are in a pitch dark environment holding your melee weapon and a flashlight in hopes that nothing will startle you, but there are many occasions where that is not necessary -- such as when you have to backtrack in areas which you have already cleared out. This can be rather irritating when you are forced by the game to walk so slowly. It feels like the developers were somehow scared that people would sprint their way through the game, breaking the immersion they tried to achieve.

The next issue which I am about to discuss is not too serious, but the forensics investigations in this game are sadly meaningless since you are always told where and what to search for. Take your scanning equipment, focalise it on the object you want to analyse, press click and presto you are the greatest forensics specialist in the world. Personally, I strongly believe this is where the game missed its biggest opportunity to deepen its gameplay. Not only that, but it could have made you feel almost like a detective, looking for clues and making deductions.

Being a very linear game is not an excuse for the repetitive gameplay. The melee combat is definitely fun and rewarding, but after a few hours you will realise that smacking people’s heads and balls is what you will be doing almost the entirety of the game. It can get tiresome after a while due to the lack of variety. Because of that, the level design can also feel a bit too claustrophobic at times with its very narrow corridors and awful FOV. See, this is where a more complex and appealing forensics mechanic could have been handy to bring some proper variety.

And lastly, while the game’s story starts out very promising, leaving the player with many questions and interpretations, it falls flat right towards the end. You can already smell the Indigo Prophecy stench from miles away, and that is one nightmare I try to not remember. The approach of “show, do not tell” which is adopted in the first three quarters of the game is well executed, because you know, a mystery is ruined the moment you bluntly explain it, but the ending kind of ruins most of that. I even think the last scene of the game nullified your entire journey.

In conclusion, Condemned: Criminal Origins ticks all the boxes for a solid psychological survival horror game. Despite some questionable design choices and a rather abysmal ending, it is singlehandedly one of the scariest experiences out there, and I am not saying that lightly. Clocking around 6-8 hours, I would say that it has about the right length, so if you like horror games, pick this one up.

One of my favorite horror video games. It's a really dark and twisted murder mystery in first-person perspective, with a lot of beefy and satisfying melee combat. The combat is very engaging and intense with smart enemy AI, almost like a fight in real life would feel like. There are guns too, but you can't rely on them completely since ammo is limited and hard to find. So when you do happen to have a gun to use, it is a special privilege. So you mainly have to resort to grabbing some 2x4 or pipe in the environment and whack some foos, usually freaky ♥♥♥ deranged hobos and psychotic killers.

You also have a bunch of very neat investigator tools and a taser that aren't just tacked on gimmicks; these mechanics actually make the gameplay very different from other FPSs. The investigation work brings some adventure/puzzle aspects to it. In fact, calling this game an FPS really doesn't describe the game as well as it ought to, nor does calling it a survival horror game or an adventure game. It's quite a special blend of all those aspects. And yes, it is scary. One of the scariest video games I can think of. And with a compelling story, if you ask me.

If you like Monolith's F.E.A.R. series, Condemned is made by those very same people and is every bit as good (perhaps even better, in terms of a horror game). If you want to play something unique and different (and also really good) in the FPS or horror genres, I highly recommend Condemned. Unfortunately, the also very very fun (but more action-y and melee combat-focused) Condemned 2 never got a PC version. Maybe someday, I hope...

Condemned: Criminal Origins is a very nice surprise for the discounted price of 3 buck something. Yeah I’m dat cheap. But I hadn’t even heard about the game until this Steam daily deal popped up. I had this vision for the original F.E.A.R. when the game came out, it was the wrong vision. I pictured a game sort of like Half-Life 2 where you walk through a creepy environment without hair raising moments and minimalistic shooting with a focus on a horror story telling.

Turns out Condemned: Criminal Origins was the original F.E.A.R. I was looking for. It was practically released at the same time as well, circa 2006. I’m guessing development was somewhat parallel.

It uses the Lithtech Jupiter EX game engine that I completely endorse … aside from the stutter-like frame rate, given the fact I didn’t feel this present in F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin (which I highly enjoyed) it must have been some bug inherent to the engine’s flagship release batch. There are 4 different types of saves which are very handy, but the Auto-Save will usually suffice on normal difficulty.

As with F.E.A.R. 2, I must say that I have been quite impressed at the amount of content that is presented level design-wise. Whenever you progress through the game, they (Monolith?) always manage to change the scenery completely and smoothly. One moment you might be outside in some playground, the next you find yourself in some school’s locker hallway, then the next you find yourself in some bloody basement. All in one map with different 3D models and textures. That’s something you don’t find often in a lot of games which choose to repeat the scenery until the next level loads.

I really don’t want to ruin this game for anyone, but Condemned: Criminal Origins had probably one of the most original boss fights I had seen in a long time. It looked heavily inspired by what I would call Sinawali (a Filipino martial arts involving sticks/batons). Most of the game combat-wise is based on melee strikes and blocking. Sometimes you will find some guns with a few shots, to which you are able to use its stock as melee on enemies that aren’t wielding a gun themselves. You also carry a Taser which is very handy for stunning your enemies for a few seconds (or frying bladder weak enemies). Although a bit of an eye-candy, there are also four optional finishing moves. The key word being optional … which some games don’t give. Add some sidekicks into the mixture and what you have is a fairly interesting combat system.

Enemy AI is impressive, they fight each other if one accidently gets hit by another. They also somehow crawl through the bottom of bookshelves and attack by popping out half way. Some even disguise themselves in a creepy abandoned store by standing still amongst mannequins. Crazy huh?

I’d say the story was mildly entertaining. It perhaps was a little slow to start off with in the beginning, but it just keeps getting better and better, including what was written during level loading screens. There are some basic investigations done like clue finding on certain visual cues. Maybe that was okay back during the PlayStation days when it was difficult to include videos in games on other gaming platforms … but these days I’d prefer more interaction to my story. I think my only quarrel with the game was perhaps the weapon, hand, phone and character 3D models. reviewText:
This is a game that throws out traditional [build tension -> release tension -> throw out a puzzle] methods of level design that most horror games employ. Instead, the terror comes simply through personal experience.
What do I mean? I mean the game itself isn't that scary. The (comically stupid) enemies are just crackheads and thugs with hoodies on, whom you could encounter just by wandering around my beautiful home city of Los Angeles for a few hours. There are little-to-none scripted jumpscares, and the game being broken up by cutscenes provides solace from the vaguely menacing environment just as some atmosphere was being built. The real terror of this game is all from the individual's experiences.
Hiding in a tiny cubicle, listening to the grunts of SEVERAL pipe-wielding druggies outside, but not knowing where they would come from.
Accidentally running into an enemy as you had your back turned.
Almost slipping off treacherous scaffolding to your death.
The real power of this game comes from simulating very real events. Though there will never be a mysterious event that causes all homeless men and meth-addicts within a hundred miles to resort to bludgening eveyone they see, all of the environments in the game are places where you would encounter someone like that. The closest in real life you'll ever come to stepping foot in Silent Hill or Mount Massive Asylum is to walk through a subway at night, or an abandoned apartment, which are both areas in the game.

So this game isn't particularly scary for everyone, it all depends on what you draw from it. With that out of the way, if you're not fazed by the situational horror of this  game, there's still plenty of content to enjoy. The controls in this game are amazing, especially if you consider that it's a port. The mouse has a certain weight to it when you swing the view, which would be annoying in a shooter but in a melee-heavy game like this it is welcome. The melee combat itself is where the game shines, as you have probably heard before. The swipe of your attack cuts through the whole screen, and the range on some of the weapons allows you to hit enemies way before they're close enough to hit you. The whole mechanic, from the powerful-looking swing to the delicious smack it makes upon hit, is just satasfying to use.

One of the game's downsides is its barren level design. Aside from the dozens upon dozens of pipes and conduits and such lying around, there are almost no collectables. Health is found in emergency kits on the wall. There are secrets called metal pieces" and "dead birds"

Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first-person horror game that I recommend a lot!
Gameplay It's a first-person beat-em-up game and also a FPS when you'll get guns.There are many melee weapons available in the game which you can find all over the levels,and also guns which are usually hidden around or you can get them from enemies.You also have a taser gun which is very useful when you want to stun and disarm enemies.

After beating an enemy,there is a chance he'll fall on his knees and allow you to do a finisher.You can do one by walking in front of him and pressing the key shown(1-Ram, 2-Slam, 3-Snap, 4-Punch).

Beside all the beating and gunning,you must also invenstigate clues(fingerprints,fluids,particles,etc.)and crime scenes using investigation tools like laser light,UV light and a camera.

During the game you can also search for collectibles.There are 2 collectibles available: dead birds and metal pieces.In every level/chapter you can find 6 dead birds and 3 metal pieces.(There are 10 levels in total)

Story You are Ethan Thomas, a crime scene investigation agent which you must journey through some condemned buildings in the search of a criminal who framed you for murder,the Serial Killer X.

Condemned is the sister game of F.E.A.R. developed around the same time for the same engine and platforms. However while F.E.A.R was a game of excess. Condemned was a game of subtlty.

In Condemned you play as a framed forensics officer who attempts to clear his name by chasing the real criminal, a serial killer. Condemned is a very rare kind of game in a sea of first person shooters. One that understands how to properly scare you and delivers an engaging story and cast of characters.

reviewText:
(this review is a lot longer than I was expecting it to be)

Condemned is an excellent non-traditional horror game where you play as the SCU (serial crime unit) agent Ethan Thomas, who was framed for the murder of two police officers with his own handgun. the fact that they never even check his gun to see the obvious fact that he wasn't the only one that used said handgun is never brought up in the game, but a minor plot convenience to kickstart the story doesn't hurt it in the long run.

the gameplay revolves around two things - investigating crime scenes and combat. unlike horror games of recent years, you can arm yourself and do stand a fighting chance against the vagrants who live in the condemned (ha ha) areas you investigate. in this regard Condemned felt highly reminiscent of F.E.A.R. (2005), in that it still manages to make you feel highly vulnerable while not stripping you away of all options to defend yourself. firearms feature sparingly, cannot be reloaded and only come equipped with a single magazine when taken from enemies.
the melee combat can definitely be described as a visceral experience, with fire axes, sledgehammers, steel pipes and conduits being among the armament you'll come across.

the investigation segments don't require much input on your end, usually only consisting of taking a couple of photos or collecting a sample of some gross stuff to send off to the SCU's lab team for analysis, but they do serve as a nice breather between the tense action sequences.

being a game from 2006, and a port of one of the very first XBOX 360 releases, the graphics are certainly quite dated, with low resolution textures and models, so if you're somebody who requires eyecandy to be able to enjoy a game you should grin and bear it you whiny baby the poor quality may be a downside, but the lighting and general atmosphere of the levels still holds up well.

the story is your standard thriller fare, you go through the levels collecting evidence and growing ever closer to catching your suspect, but it somewhat jumps the shark during the last 30 minutes or so of the game and suddenly changes the game from being (mostly) grounded in reality to some really strange supernatural ♥♥♥♥ that is kind of a mess and feels like the developers had to think of a conclusion 30 minutes before the release of the game. maybe it's explained in the sequel.

unfortunately, the sequel, Condemned: Bloodshot, hasn't seen a PC release as of writing, so if you're left wanting more after completion, you'll have to get a copy on the 360/PS3. of course, purchasing Criminal Origins shows that there's a demand for it, but you never really know with SEGA.

overall, Condemned is definitely a horror experience that's worth a shot, if only to get away from the masses of shovelware that the horror game genre has pushed out recently, though seeing as it took me only 5 and a half hours to complete the campaign, you may want to wait for a sale.

Pros:Creepy and uneasy atmosphere that can lead to scares.
An interesting story that reveals itself at the right pace.
Melee combat is fun with improvised weapons found in the environment: conduit pipes, short pipes, long pipes, plus non-pipe items like axes and 2x4s.
Finish off your opponent with one of four animated finishers, which is neat.
Enemy AI can be interesting  -- they engage with each other or wait for you behind a pillar.
A flashlight that does not need batteries.Cons:Graphics show their age
Story does leave some gaps. Probably because it was meant to be continued
Condemned 2: Bloodshot was only released for Xbox 360 and Playstation 3
Guns are terrible
Movement up and down stairs is unreasonably slow, though for an odd reason improves later in the game
Very little in the way of replayability.
Gameplay
Atmosphere: Dark, tight corridors, curious sounds, enemy variety that hide in the shadows. All add to an uneasy setting that can heighten senses and create scare moments.
Investigating: As an FBI agent you’ll have all types of data collecting tech to take samples and send back to the lab and tech agent Rosa. These moments help progress the story while breaking up the combat gameplay.
Melee combat: This is enjoyable and satisfying to get involved with. It’s possible to find any weapon lying around from a desk to 2x4 with bolts. Combat will involve an attack or block, by blocking you will open up the opponent for a counter attack. Blocking can take a little getting used to, but is imperative to learn to survive the game. If you beat the enemy AI enough you will open up an option for a finisher. A finisher could be one of four options to snap a neck or slam them into the ground. On top of all that you have a taser gun that you can use to stun someone, take their weapon or a cheap shot.
Gunplay: All round just bad, doesn’t feel right. Necessary in some circumstances, but melee combat trumps it.
Difficulty: There was only a few times I felt challenged, once you gain the experience with melee combat, the game gets easier.
Level design: As a linear game you would expect the level design to hold up to keep it interesting, and it does -- from different locales to tight corridors.
Replayability: With these type of scare games, the best experience is the first, because playing it over you know what you are facing around the corner and with that lessens the fear. There is the added option of collecting items for achievements. But these achievements are in-game not related to any Steam achievements. I did not notice if they unlocked any new moddable options.

reviewText:
Week Long Deal! Only 2,50 EUR for this masterpiece! It would be a sin not to pick this one up till the offer lasts.

I did not know Monolith did not become defunct but was acquired by Warner Bros. I thought they'd really stopped developing video games for good. This all happened around the time they came out with Condemned. It was interesting to play this game after FEAR which was action-packed and you needed to quickly react and shoot enemies - at the same time the bullet time concept made it all easier.

So, when Condemned came out and I saw this game did not really have any weapons in it I took a step back. I mean, melee can certainly be interesting but FPS games were never about close combat but by utilising a certain assortment of ranged weaponry. Yet, Monolith managed to make the game interesting till the very end by incorporating an exciting and mysterious storyline.

You play an FBI agent who becomes a fugitive after a killer frames him for the murder of a police officer. Thomas, while hiding from the cops, tries to uncover the truth and visit long abandoned (condemned) buildings to find clues as to who this mysterious Serial Killer X might be. Throughout the game you can grab almost any object you come across. Steel pipes, planks, crowbar and even a fire axe is at your disposal to get rid of your enemies. These are not necessarily people you are after, but people who occupy these buildings - petty criminals or junkies just seconds away from a lethal overdose.

Occasionally, the game lets you do some crime scene investigations. This happens when Thomas reaches a new milestone in his investigation: you have a variety of gadgets at your disposal with which you can collect samples and send them to your lab analyst - the only person who trusts you - for further analysis. That is how you can progress and go through warehouses, an old school, a library or the deadly sewers and eventually you'll reach an orchard to finally face the antagonist of the game.

Condemned has an appalling story and makes you stuck in your chair until you complete the story and find out the fate of agent Thomas. It has a creepy atmosphere and it truly is a psychological horror. I do not know exactly how many such games are out there for the PC but this is certainly one of the classics.

Once you pick this up and complete it you'll find out why I hate the developers for never releasing the sequel on PC.

reviewText:
Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first person survival horror game that tells the story of Ethan Thomas, an FBI agent framed for the murder of two police officers, who is now on the run to find the real murderer and uncover the reason for the suddenly increased violence in the city.



Being developed by Monolith Productions and released shortly after the original F.E.A.R., you will notice a a lot of parallels between those two games in terms of story telling, visual style, atmosphere, lighting effects and so on, which, gameplay-wise, makes Condemnd a better 'sequel' to F.E.A.R. than F.E.A.R. 2 was.



The story itself isn't exactly mind-blowing, but it keeps you going and the more you get to know about the happenings in the city and the identity of the serial killer, the more it all makes sense.



As the game was originally developed for the XBox360, the controls are fairly basic stuff for a first person game. The only thing I kind of disliked is the lack of ability to jump in the game. It's not a deal breaker, but it definitely limits the freedom of movement as you always have to find a staircase, a ramp or similar to get to slightly higher places.



While the game *is* first person and you *do* get to find weapons to shoot with, I won't go as far and call it a first person shooter because the action is clearly designed around melee combat. You will find projectile weapons like pistols, shotguns etc. throughout the game, but they are rather rare and mostly only contain a few bullets. If the magazine is empty, you can't reload the gun and will have to use it as a melee weapon instead. Most of the time you will be searching the enviroment for other melee weapons like pipes, desk drawers, fire axes, sledge hammers, wood planks and so on. They all have unique stats in terms of damage, speed, range and block, so you might want to try them all out instead of sticking to one type of weapon.



Since you are a FBI agent, you also get to use a couple tech gadgets to analyze blood stains, finger prints, DNA trails and so on. At various key points in the game, the HUD will tell you to use the gear, so you will have to search a room or an entire area for evidence. It's a neat little addition and adds a welcome change to the otherwise entirely puzzle-free gameplay.



Graphics-wise, the game doesn't provide you with too many options and, like many console games, suffers from low-resolution textures. The atmospheric lighting manages to cover that up for the most part, but in brighter areas it gets quite obvious. Then again, the game was released in 2005 and considering there are games released in 2010 and earlier that look worse, one can hardly complain here.



One of the slightly more outstanding aspects of the game is the enemy AI. You will find the enemies run away from you and hide behind corners when you aim your flashlight at them, they will wait out for the right moment to flank you, eventually will beat up other thugs if they stand between them and you and so on. The AI is not that extremely complex, but then again, a lot of recent cover-based third person shooters don't manage to do that.



While the campaign felt relatively long, it only took me roughly 6 hours to beat. There are no additional game modes or a multiplayer mode, so once you are done with the story, you can either re-play it or simply move on as, apart from finding all collectible items, there's nothing else to do in the game.



So, if you liked the original F.E.A.R. and want to play a game with the same unique style, make sure to give Condemned: Criminal Origins a shot as this is the closest to F.E.A.R. you can get.

Additionally, the voiceacting and dialog are both terrible, which creates a sort of harmonic resonance that serves to make both even more grating. You know the way that the smell/sight of vomit or rotting eggs has a tendency to make a person want to throw up? Well, imagine if someone ate whole rotten eggs (shells still on) and then threw them up in some kind of frenzy of blood-filled chunks and nasty egg yolks  -- it would be far more off-putting than either individual gross-out.

Still, it's an enjoyable game, and well worth it if you can get it cheap.

Ah, Condemned: Criminal Origins.

The game looks OK, graphics are kinda in the ballpark for 2006 technology and some would argue they don't age well. The plot is a bit generic and forgettable, so don't expect a Spielberg-caliber story. Replayability isn't very good; once you're through, you've pretty much seen it all. For a long time, I found this game in a bargain bin.

I'd imagine you're a little confused. If you look up, it says that I recommend this game.

Those things that I griped about above are all negligible (at least for me). You don't buy this game because it doesn't look like Crysis nor do you buy it because the story will enthrall you like To The Moon. You buy this game because it will scare you.

The sounds and environments alone were enough to make me contemplate turning the game off in fear before I even saw any sort of threat. Dark, derelict locations such as abandoned shopping malls, run-down subways, and remote farmhouses with an eerie soundtrack (fun fact: the soundtrack sometimes makes use of subtle shepherd's tones) drive the tense feeling of this game. When the atmosphere turns hostile and enemies rear their heads, you'll be seeing a range of things from ugly street thugs to nightmarish abominations.

Great melee combat with solid controls help you wade through the horror, as firearms are a scarce commodity. You'll play most of the game weilding a pipe, electrical conduit, fire axe, or anything else that you find in the environment around you. Combat is engaging and satisfying; you'll be planning your melee strikes and kicks while blocking your enemy's attacks, sometimes executing a finishing move.

I'm a big fan of this game, and how easily scared I am playing horror games I definitely got a lot more than my money's worth. If you can look past some drawbacks, this game is a great experience at an even greater value for it's price.

reviewText:
Condemned: Criminal Origins is a story about the least athletic man in existence. You play a disgraced FBI agent, a man who the story tells us has almost abnormally high muscle and bone density, but who in the game is uncapable of walking over knee high fences or running more than a few seconds without needing half a minute to catch his breath. From this, an entire game is born.

The game is a horror title, with the gameplay built around exploring abandoned facilities in a city gripped by madness. Deranged citizens constantly attack you as you explore, and very little of the combat is performed with guns. Almost everything is done with melee weapons taken from objects lying around. There is a satisfying clunkiness to the combat, but its simplicity lacks depth, and there's little else meaningful to take its places,

The melee weapons also take the place that keys and keycards would in other games- a sledgehammer is needed to open some doors, a crowbar others, etc. This becomes contrived when the obstacles to get past are something like a piano blocking a stairway. In this world, no one is capable of climbing or jumping.

In some of the later levels there are genuine chills to be found, but the gamplay feels rote most of the time. The pace is glacial, and for most of the game you are stuck exploring these places at a slow walking pace. Whenever a story sequence takes places, you are confined to a tiny area, unable to walk ahead. There are quite a number of moments, none of which are interesting, and the wait to continue the level can be agonizing.

The story is preposterous, almost farcical, with motivations that make zero sense and a clueless protagonist. There's a major disconnnect between the protagonist's motivations and the actions the player takes.  It's hard to care about catching a serial killer who kills other serial killers in a game where the primary mechanics consist of the player killing hundreds homeless people.

I'm surprised the title took less than 6 hours. It felt like so much more. People interested in this game can walk-very slowly- away.

reviewText:
Have you ever had a nightmare where you just can't move? You move slowly as if wading through mud, can't jump over obstacles or crouch under them, while being pursued by howling madmen? This is that nighmare. I mean, christ almighty it's slow. I'm not one to normally complain about a meandering pace but this is absolutely glacial. It's very atmospheric, but it'd be more atmospheric if I didn't move like a sumo wrestler on a treadmill.

That said, I can see what the appeal is - or at least, what it was back in the days - in that the game is pretty effective at scaring you and making strung-out drug addicts genuinely menacing. The melee combat is... well, it's a matter of taste. If you really get used to it it's passable and a fair bit more visceral than most games (though not as good as Zeno Clash) but it's a pretty tough learning curve to get used to. The character moves incredibly slowly even in combat.

That's not the end of the problems. The game talks about achivements and how you unlock them, but doesn't actually have achivements. Good job, Sega! The collectibles are tedious to find thanks to the snail's pace you move at, and they don't actually unlock anything useful (like a speed upgrade). You can't take bullets from weapons to use them in others, even if they're the same gun, so once a gun is spent just throw it away like a cheeseburger wrapper. Your protagonist carries around a literal ton of analytic equipment but can only hold one weapon, because apparently two handguns is just over his capacity.

I can't recommend it, which is frustrating, because it feels like a flawed gem. Sadly, it's more flawed than gem, at least if you're entering this without nostalgia.

reviewText: When it comes to horror in gaming, I'm gonna be honest: I find horror in gaming to be laughable to the point of not even being scary. Games like Slender, FEAR, FNaF, SCP, all they do is just make me laugh and never scream in horror. Sure, some might make me flinch a bit, but that's it. WIth that said, I had a lot of recommendations for 'Condemned: Criminal Origins' for a while now, with people saying that it's one of the best FPS and scariest games out there. Well, I'd like to know what game they were playing, cause this game is not the game they were talking about. This might be one of the worst games I've played in a long while. The horror elements are laughable to the point where they are BORING. When it comes to the much touted combat, it's lame. All you do is just left click to swing or fire your weapon, right click to block, space to kick and that's it. I dunno, I guess I'm use to more refined FPS combat in games like Zeno Clash and Mirror's Edge, but I expected a bit more when it came to this game with all the praise it got. I mostly stuck with the firearms whenever I found them or tasering the opponent, to which I found the taser can make most fights end in seconds with one well tase and one well hit with your weapon. The one good thing I will say about this game is that, well, the detective gameplay is pretty fun. Granted, it's not as involved as most games with this feature, but, nonetheless, it is fun. Now, I'm not one to harp on graphics (to me, graphics are not a selling point in a game), but WOW! Does this game look ugly! Even if I did get this on Day One, I'd probably think it's ugly! The character models are janky and not pleasing to look at (even the normal characters suffer this fate). The only other good thing I'll say is that the dialouge is well acted and fun to listen to....coming from the normal characters. The psychos dialouge are just cliched bad guys who want to bash your brains in dialogue. Out of all the games I've played, this is, hands down, one of the worst I played in a long while. Sadly, that means I can not recommend this to anyone at all. If you want a game that does first-person combat better, play either Zeno Clash games or Mirror's Edge. If you want a game that does horror good, get either the first or second F.E.A.R or Amnesia. Just avoid this game.

reviewText:
Wasted all of my bullets in the first level, bad guy steals my gun and threatens to kill me with it. Proceeds to kill both of my partners with my 0 bullet gun. Actually, it seems that many of the homeless drug addicts you kill in this game have the ability to literally sweat bullets and proceed to use them to kill you, since while the shotgun I retrieved from a locked safe only had 3 bullets in it, the hobo around the corner had at least 15 rounds for his shotgun. I guess having strong enemies, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mechanics, and dark lit maps counts is all it takes to count as a horror game.

I know I've only played an hour, and maybe it gets decent further on, but I didn't enjoy a single moment of the time I played. For a game that revolves around investigating and fighting, it's got some of the worst mechanics for both.

All of the enemies I've fought so far have been actual drug addicted homeless guys that really have it out for me for no other reason than they're addicts. The melee combat is terrible. Your attacks are either too slow to attack consecutively or aren't strong enough to stun enemies. There's a 100% damage block you can use, but it's very hard to predict when they'll attack, as their recoil animations and their attack animations are nearly identical.

Gunplay is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. You're only ever going to find guns with enough ammo for one, maybe two kills. You're then forced to use the gun as a melee weapon, where's it's good for a hit or three before breaking and doing negligable damage. Why use the gun as a melee weapon? Because this FBI agent apparently decided to burn his weapon holster after his gun was stolen, so you have to choose between carrying a gun and carrying an actual melee weapon.

As for the investigating, it's so far literally just walking around with a magic tool out until you find a glowy bit, then you take a second tool to scan it or take a picture. There's one part where you follow a trail only visible with your tool, except that it's through a linear area and the story progressed without needing to use the tool. That's it. It's not any kind of puzzle, unless you count having to look at the controls layout every so often, since they didn't bother to give you any of the keybindings in game.

Another big annoyance is medkit spacing. I'll find three in one area, use one, and decide not to waste the other two, so I progress, take some damage in the next fight, but when I go back for my medkit, the previous door has been mysteriously closed forever. I suspect this has to do with the game's age, and it needing to unload the previous area in order to load the current. It's still really annoying to have to clear a whole nother area before finding another cluster of medkits. You can find some randomly hidden in closets or on desks, but in a game where one enemy can take out nearly your full health bar if you trade blows, I think carrying medkits would have been a better choice.

While I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the mechanics, the sprint feature is just terrible. You get a few seconds of hardly noticable speed increase and the bar takes ages to refill, to the point you've already forgotten about sprinting by the time it's refilled.

And while I'm at it, I want to talk about how stupid the game's premise is as well. Early game spoilers ahead.

So, as far as I'd gotten, the main motivation for our hero, Ethan Thomas, is that the serial killer he's hunting stole his gun (again, out of bullets) and used it to kill the cops I worked with. The local police force decides it's much more likely that what actually happened is a seasoned investigator decided to out of the blue kill the officers helping him on his case. At least, that's what the mysterious weirdo who showed up in Ethan's apartment said. I'm convinced this guy was just trying to make me look even more guilty by running from the police, but I don't care to play long enough to find out.

Maybe I would have enjoyed it a decade ago when it released, but compared to other games you could buy today for $15, Condemned: Criminal Origins is a waste of time and money.

reviewText:
I saw this on a top ten scariest games list so I decided to give it a go.

Condemned: CO does have atmosphere that is immersive and mildly creepy (complemented by a gloomy soundtrack). This is the strongest aspect of the game and it is this, along with the semi-engaging story (with the hope for a satisfying ending or something that could conjure an interesting idea), that compelled to me play through to the end.

After it was all over, I was ultimately dissapointed with this as a survival horror title. For one, there were no puzzles (which are a staple of the genre). Instead, you have fetch quests (i.e. find sledgehammer to break lock on door or find valve someplace to turn off steam). The fetch quests are not even difficult because the levels are fairly linear and you are not given the option to interact with many objects outside anything that can be used as a melee weapon.

The enemies (maybe with the exception of the mannequins in the department store), were not disturbing at all. And this is a major complaint for a survival horror game because it, unfortantely, bogged down the dread/scare factor quite a bit. Most of the time, you'll encounter hobos running at or away from you with x melee weapon. To the game's credit, there are well executed jump-scares at times, but for the most part you see it coming (even when they are hiding behind a wall with one arm clearly hanging out).

Combat system is clunky, as it should be in this type of game, but becomes repetitious after awhile. Thus, it doesn't feel clunky anymore and engagments with enemies felt more like busywork instead of terrifying encounters. The melee weapons do vary in damage and speed but the technique (block, hit, hit, repeat) remained the same. Occasionally you can find a firearm to spice things up a bit but primarily you will be using a melee weapon.

When the story wrapped up, I was underwhelmed which was a shame because the set up was decent and had potential. This would've been forgivable if there were in-depth character examinations. Yes, you do learn about the characters but it's nothing extensive that makes you either connect with them or intrigues the mind. Thus, I had no desire to replay the game for the story/characters at all.

If you're a fan of atmospheric games and on the fence, then I would recommend getting it on discount because, for all its faults, it does have redeeming qualties that made me (somewhat) glad I played it. It's possible that you might find the experience more terrifying than I did because, after all, horror is subjective. However, if you are looking for a game on par with something like Amnesia in terms of horror, then I'd pass this one up.

5.0/10

I originally played this on the XBox 360 when it was first released and decided to see how much better the PC version was, and I also wanted to play it again.

PC version is a solid 60 FPS even when I was streaming with almost no slowdown. Other than that, the graphics didn't seem any better than the 360 version. Keep in mind, this game is VERY old, and what I consider a classic. In its time, the graphics were pretty good, but it certainly has not aged well, so bare this in mind. The story for its time was very interesting and easy to follow with a satisfying ending.

Mouse and Keyboard controls are more effective than using a Controller, as FPS games tend to be. You rely more on melee weapons but guns are still useful, just limited in ammunition and you can't reload them, but you can use them as blunt weapons once you've run out of ammo until you find something better.

The game can be brutal and even on Normal you'll get hit hard at times, so it might be a bit of a challenge. On what is now my 3rd playthrough of this game total (1st two being on the 360), I beat it in 7 hours without going out of my way for the collectibles. It might take you 10 hours on your first playthrough, more if you intend to get as many collectibles as possible.

It's a satisfying experience and if you're not new to video games and just happened to miss this gem, or you enjoy Horror games and aged graphics don't bother you, I highly recommend this game. If you're new to games, don't really care for story, and/or Graphics mean a lot to you, eh, maybe look elsewhere.

Let Monolith take you through a joyride with creepy atmosphere, scary visual effects that keep you on edge, a great story, and satisfying gameplay. Condemned Criminal Origins is a game where you play as FBI Detective Ethan Thomas who is framed by a serial killer for the deaths of his fellow officers. The only thing he can do is prove his innocence by tracking down the killer. But it's not a simple walk in the park, along the way you will fight violent civilians whose number has been growing in the city recently.

The enemies themselves are so scary because they seem like regular people from far away but every time you get close to take a swing you see their messed up demonic faces. It's really cool. The enemies kind of behave how I imagine crack heads would. They usually have a melee weapon with them but they can, if forced to, grab a weapon from the map. Combat is really satisfying as you can swing, block (which causes a stun if done successfully), and kick. It's kind of like Kirby games because you can get different weapons mid-level that you choose depending on your mood (except for the scary crack heads). There are also guns in the game. Both you and the enemy can use it. The guns are more like a Get out of jail free card because it usually kills an enemy with one shot. There's also a taser but it's similar to the gun because it makes things too easy (except for one situation).

The investigation scenes are also better than the ones in F.E.A.R. In F.E.A.R you are given more pieces to the puzzle of what is going on by pushing E on a computer and letting your friend talk about what you found. In this game you have to use forensic tools to find the clues rather than hit a simple button. For me it’s more satisfying to use the tools because you actually see the evidence and hear the results of its analysis.

Only con of the game is that your character walks SO SLOW. His sprint is as fast as a normal walking speed but it only lasts 5 seconds. This is bad for two reasons. One there are collectable birds and metal pieces that you can find in the level. How do you expect me to explore when I am so slow. I go to a place where I think there will be a bird, there isn't, I try to run back to the path but I run out of sprint, I cry from frustration. The second reason why the running speed is bad is because some enemies (only a few each level) have guns. So you have to run towards them and take them out but you can't do that because you are so slow. The only way around it is to use a gun or the taser.

Nonetheless this is a great horror game that gets under your skin rather than relies on jump scares. Definitely get it if you like F.E.A.R.

This is a very old game, so I'm not sure how useful this review is. I guess someone might read it, considering it's up for sale on the Steam store.

Anyway. Decent game, mainly focused on melee. Graphics are very decent for the time, though you do have to jump through some hoops to make the engine actually work and give decent framerates (usually fixable by disabling HID devices in Control Panel -> System). The gameplay itself is pretty good, guns are pretty widely available so I actually used them most of the time. You are for some reason hamstrung with the limitation that you cannot carry more than 1 weapon at a time, even if it's something that you could conceivably stick in your pocket, like the .45 pistol. I guess your taser is already taking up all of your pockets. The walk speed in this game is hideously slow and the sprint meter goes down WAY too quickly, especially when you have to game the system and run back and forth killing dudes and then running back to caches of more guns (after all, our hero can't carry spare shotgun shells in his coat pocket).

Sound design is pretty nice, very atmospheric and oppressive. There were a couple places where the music is too loud and jarring. The jump scares were mostly pretty predictable but thankfully there weren't too many of them.

This game surprised me the most with the length. It feels longer than it really is, but I beat it first time through in 6 hours. For a game without much replay value (it's essentially a corridor with cutscenes), that's not very long. And even then, it probably felt longer because the gameplay was beginning to wear on me.

I'm on the fence with this one. If it had a little more content, I might be more willing to recommend it. As it stands, though... buy it if it's 75% off or something. I would have trouble justifying paying more than 7-8 dollars for it.

Condemned: Criminal Origins is a psychological first-person horror game that has managed to stand the test of time as well as any other title from its era. This is thanks in large part to the game's visceral combat system which focuses on melee weapons, as well as an intense atmosphere that will keep you constantly wondering what's just around the corner. This creepy atmopshere is further developed by quality level design and some good use of lighting and sound effects. Enemy AI is mostly intelligent; your psychotic opposition will sneak around quietly, strafe and block effectively, and won't just whale away on you when they see you. However, while the game holds up just fine from a gameplay and mechanics standpoint, there are some muddy textures and awkward character models that are less than appealing when compared to more modern games.\n\nIf you're looking for a game that can provide some solid thrills and an immensely satisfying combat system, Condemned: Criminal Origins is as good as it gets. An underappreciated title that plays just as well today as it did 7-8 years ago.

It's basically a horror game with melee combat, so not exactly your traditional shooter (though guns can be used in the game). It's the creepy, tense kind of horror, and while there are a few jump scares, fear comes from the tense atmosphere.

It's also worth keeping in mind that this game was released about ten years ago, and it shows, especially when it comes to game design. Condemned adheres to old game design philosophies, such as slow walking speed, backstory told via loading screen and documents (which are locked behind collectables), locking areas behind doors that can be broken only after a certain weapon has been found, etc.
These are not negative points; they're just part of the deal - old game, old design. But if you have patience, you'll find a wonderful game, with beautiful level design (albeit linear), wonderful melee combat and a tense horror atmosphere.

The only negative is that the game doesn't really make any efforts of explaining the story, so you'll have to collect all birds and metals to get some additional documents that explain the story. But it's worth it and I can say I definitely recommend this game. It's an old gem.

reviewText:
In Condemned: Criminal Origins, the goal of the game is to move through mostly linear, filthy buildings in an urban environment, occasionally deviating from the obvious path to pick up meaningless collectibles, such as engraved pieces of metal and dead birds. During these treks, the player uses a variety of improvised and non-improvised weaponry to fend off legions of greasy hobos, pale-skinned crack ♥♥♥♥♥s, acrobats who cosplay as Sméagol, and f̶a̶t̶t̶i̶e̶s̶ tumblr users. There are light elements of forensic and puzzle gameplay that keep the story going, a narrative which is surprisingly easy to follow.

The game is plagued by awkward combat, usually the fault of indiscernible attack reach, as well as a number of weird design choices. Some sort of make sense, in sacrificing logic for the sake of gameplay. I can understand why the player isn't allowed to pick up ammo, as the guns give a huge advantage, but other times it looks the developers got lazy in their planning. Why are there so many invisible walls? Why do defeated enemies take so long to telegraph their helplessness before I get options to perform special finishes? Why is there even a toggle for the flashlight?

Actually, I take that back. There is only one reason to ever turn the flashlight off: when a pronounced visual effect comes onto the screen and intensifies the already high contrast. Otherwise, it might as well be kept on for the entire game. Often, it's dark enough to justify using it, it's not on a timer so it can be used whenever, and it doesn't do anything to alert the enemies to my presence. In fact, the enemies might as well not even exist until I pass a certain invisble threshold and they spring into the level with their canned, predictable routines.

That's my main issue with this game, is how nearly every moment designed to deliver on the suspense is a triggered event which usually fails in this endeavor. Sure, other things, like cleverly-placed objects to trip over and ominously-moving furniture help to build that sense of dread, but when it comes time to actually scare the player, it's frequently something that can be seen a mile ahead of time, such as the truck-sized blobs of meat that think they can hide behind corners without getting stuck on said corners.

Yet, as much as I've been ripping it a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this one is alright, at least for one playthrough. It's an odd combination of atmosphere, combat, and puzzles that would seem mediocre on their own, but coagulate here into a unique, if at first glance lackluster, experience.
